entry.question: What is the purpose of the HaplowebMaker program?
entry.answer: HaplowebMaker is a program capable of creating Haploweb representations from FASTA alignments.

entry.question: So and what is a Haploweb?
entry.answer: Haplowebs are graphical representations. Haplowebs are haplotype networks that also show which haplotypes co-occur in at least one individual of the dataset. Haplowebs have been first purposed by Jean-François Flot in his paper Haplowebs as a graphical tool for delimiting species: a revival of Doyle's "field for recombination" approach and its application to the coral genus Pocillopora in Clipperton

entry.question: How does it work?
entry.answer:
When the default settings are used, HaplowebMaker first calculates the evolutionary relationship of the sequences (haplotype network) via the Median-Joining-Algorithm. Afterwards the haplotype network gets visualized via a force directed graph drawing algorithm. Last, Bézier curves are added in order to connect those haplotypes that co-occur in at least one individual in the dataset.
However, the user has an influence on this procedure. Like this it is possible to choose another algorithm to calculate the evolutionary relationship.

entry.question: Is there a way to edit/improve the created Haploweb representation?
entry.answer: Yes, HaplowebMaker provides a specialized Image-editor that can get used to give each Haploweb a final touch. As HaplowebMaker creates standard svg-images, it is also possible to edit the created Haplotype images in programs (like Inkscape) that support this file type.
